title: Hudspeth: UL got back to Cajun football in win
text:
Hudspeth: UL got back to Cajun football in win Bobby Ardoin, Special to the Daily World 6:59 p.m. CDT October 12, 2015 UL coach Mark Hudspeth was impressed with the toughness displayed by running back Elijah McGuire in Saturday’s win over Texas State. (Photo: Mike Curley/Daily World) CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
LAFAYETTE – Mark Hudspeth is starting to recognize the traditional characteristics in his UL offense and he says that’s encouraging. 
The Cajuns, Hudspeth said on Monday, are back to playing what he calls “Ragin’ Cajuns football, something his said was evident in last Saturday night’s 49-27 Sun Belt Conference victory over Texas State. 
What’s Ragin’ Cajuns football? 
Hudspeth had a definition ready at his weekly Monday press conference. 
“”It’s the type of football that we’ve been used to, which is playing physically and playing very tough. 
Also we’re once again getting the ball to our playmakers,” Hudspeth said. 
Hudspeth said the physical element especially in the Cajuns’ offensive game was a missing element as his team began the season 1-3. 
Against Texas State, Hudspeth said he saw a different offensive perspective. 
“I think we weren’t spreading the ball around enough. (Against Texas State) I saw so many other people making a contributions. 
“That’s really when your offense can click,” said Hudspeth. 
Hudspeth said junior quarterback Jalen Nixon, who started against Texas State, did a good job of making sure running back Elijah McGuire and wide receiver Jamal Robinson said ample chances to make plays. 
McGuire carried 28 times for 170 yards. 
There were other options that Nixon also noticed, Hudspeth said. 
Pass receivers Al Riles (9 receptions, 98 yards), Robinson (4-67-2 touchdowns, and Gabe Fuselier 5-51) helped the Cajuns move the ball. 
Nixon thew only seven incompletions off 29 attempts. He passed for 238 yards and three touchdowns in addition to rushing for 45. 
Hudspeth said Nixon, who has been polishing his offensive skills, has continued to improve. 
That means Nixon will be the UL starting quarterback until further notice. 
“As the season has gone on, he has gotten more reps and gotten better. He’s been showing progress on a good, natural curve. 
“(Nixon) has really played six good quarters of football (two at Kentucky, four against Texas State. As he improves, he can really help us. 
“Some of the passes he threw the other night were really darts,” Hudspeth said. 
McGuire, also a junior, is becoming more of a complete back, said Hudspeth. 
“He is way more durable and he is a completely different style back than he was two years ago. He can punch it inside, get it our on the perimeter or get it on outside where he makes people miss,” Hudspeth said. 
NEXT GAME: The Cajuns won’t play this Saturday. Instead UL begins preparations for next Tuesday night’s nationally televised game at Arkansas State.
